												IL-2 Sturmovik: 1946 is a game unlike many, and this can be for better or for worse. If you get this game, one of the first things that you will notice about it, is that it isn't exactly the easiest game to learn to like. The tutorials that are available to you do not put you at the controls of the aircraft you're being taught to fly, but rather make you watch another person fly it the way it's supposed to be flown. Really, the only true way you can learn to play the game is to start it up, and begin playing it immediatly. No tutorials, no help. Trust me, you will die. A lot.I'm going to go ahead and tell you the things that you likely won't like about this game at first. 1: There are no "Real" tutorials that teach you how to play as I've said before, meaning the only way for you to learn to play the game is through jumping right in.2: The controls and flight characteristics are very realistic, meaning that if you haven't played a Flight Simulator before, there are hundreds of ways that you can screw yourself over without actually getting into combat, such as putting yourself into a Flat Spin, Stalling Out, Ripping Your Wings, Overheating Your Engine, etc.3: There can literally be a use for every single button on your keyboard, meaning that hitting one wrong button can mean instant death.4: This game is unbelievably difficult to master in terms of everything, from flight controls to maneuvers to landing.With all of these negativities said, it doesn't sound like a very fun game, now does it? That's where you're wrong. I believe that the people that made this game were absolute geniuses. This is the number one thing about this game - you need to be patient. You will die several times before actually learning to kill anything, but once you do learn, once the little mechanism inside your brain clicks with this game, it will be one of the most fun World War Two Flight Simulators you've ever played. The Bottom Line is, this game isn't for people that give up easily. This game is for people who are patient, and people who are willing to learn. Do I recommend this game? Yes, yes I do, but only if you are willing to learn the complexities of it. If not, then don't waste your time with it.

												"Il-2 Sturmovik: 1946" originally began as an Eastern Front flight combat simulator which branched into Europe, The Pacific and then into the immediate Post-war Jet era. It has become a bit of a cult following with several loyal players continually playing, hosting, creating skins, missions and campaigns. It is probably one of the longest running dedicated combat sims which though using a limited and dated engine, is still able to satisfyingly emulate the widest scope of aviation combat centered around World War 2 in varying difficulty levels and complexity. It has over 150 flyable aircraft from varying aspects of nearly all theaters of operations as well as associated maps. It includes pilot campaigns from nearly all sides, a quick mission builder and a full mission builder. But most of it's contemporary strengths come from beautifully made skins, missions, campaigns and utilities from it's many followers and fans that run the gamut of historical to flights of fantasy. It's latest version is 4.12.2m (which is the latest steam version - No patching needed!) which has been officially updated by a group called Team Daidalos (rumor has it they are even working on 4.13!) has added flyable aircraft, tweaked graphics and sounds and additional mission building options and objects. (it even now has the option to add 3rd party "Online sounds" and still be a 'stock' game) It's multiplayer capability is via Hyperlobby where you can usually fly and/or host missions, join dedicated server maps, or get limited help from people there.Besides the stock game, many have added one of the popular mods to add even more popular aircraft, different flight models, digitized sounds, improved graphics and mission building options and objects. (Most mods can be switched to stock easily via a simple program).It has the added advantage of being able to run smoothly (A critical point in combat flight sims) on most older systems.oh, I have purchased 2 retail box versions and the steam version so I've played a bit more than 10 minutes..  :)(I have "Il-2:Cliffs of Dover" and "Il-2: Battle of Stalingrad" and I still enjoy "Il-2 Sturmovik:1946)

												Written as of 25 August, 2016.I grew up with this game, so I may be severely biased, just a warning. I remember getting the original IL-2 Sturmovik/Pacific Fighters pack way back in 2005 as a starry-eyed little kid. I was fascinated with aircraft from this era and it's the main reason I know how much about them I do today. And then, suddenly, this new, vastly superior version appeared! I never begged my parents for something so badly in my life, but I NEEDED this as a child. And so I made the money to buy it. Best idea ever. It doesn't show it, but the amount I have played this game in so many situations must easily be at least 4,000 hours before getting it on Steam alone. But enough of my life story, let's get into the review of this.What makes this game appeal to someone like me? Vast amounts of aircraft stock in the game, hundreds of AI ground/naval vehicles to populate maps, and the fact that there's actually a very intuitive mission maker within the game itself. Throw in one of the newest massive modpacks (CUP/HSFX/DBW/etc.) and you're suddenly thrown into a game with hundreds of aircraft, amazing graphics, great missions, historical skins, and even more ground/naval cannon fodder. I greatly appreciate the attention to detail (especially for a game released in 2006) and historical value of this game. Some things aren't perfect, but hell, this was released almost a whole decade ago and is still rated as one of the best WWII Combat Flight Simulators out there.Well, that's great and all, but what are some dislikes? Well, I would say the graphics are fairly bad, but I cut it major slack for being made in 2006. There's also the incessant lawnmower for 90% of stock aircraft engines. Plus that music. I love the original 2003 vibes of the original and Pacific Fighters combined, but after playing both for 11 years, that has gotten under my skin to the point of muting the music. Some of the controls are difficult to master, and the game itself takes years to master. Hell, when I first started the series, it♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off. The tutorials and such are honestly shoddy and you really can't play this well without a joystick, but with even a low quality one in your hands, you can become proficient. All of my dislikes besides the joystick near-necessity (not really a complaint in my opinion) are with the stock game, and mods 100% cure all.Pros:Held up to time amazingly wellCan be very relaxingAmazing 3D models (for the time)Great flight characteristicsIn-game mission editorMillions of options for custom missionsNear-overwhelming amounts of mods due to roughly 10 communities, creating a very customizable environmentCons:Graphics (Can be easily modded)Sounds and Music (Again, mods)Lack of hands-on tutorialsAlmost requires joystick (But it's a simulator, not some arcade game)Overall:9/10. My all-time favorite WWII FCS, and one I've easily sunk thousands of hours into before adding to Steam. Supreme amounts of replay value, obscene amounts of content, and the best installment (personal opinion) in the series that set the foundation for modern WWII Flight Combat Simulation games to this day.

The only gripe some may have are the interior visuals - they look very dated. They are, however, immersive, and entirely 3d, so It isn't unplayable. The exterior visuals really hold up well. If you compare it to BoS or Even "Rise of Flight" you can tell it's a bit older, but it still looks good. The worst textures come from ground units - tanks, jeeps, AA positions, all look like theyre from the 1990's, but since you won't see them for more than a second, I really don't notice.If you're a Win 10 user, thinking about trying the more expensive BoS, maybe give this a try - I find myself playing it more than its hotter, newer sibling.:::UPDATE:::I ordered a USB Bluetooth adapter for my PC, as I play several controller-based games also. 												A brief review on the, First person, War based flight simulator, game titled: IL-2 Sturmovik: 1946Gameplay:In IL-2, you have the ability to play as either the Allies or the enemies from World War II. Please note that this game is one large bundle of five separate games. Which are all bundled into the single game IL-2. This game focuses on realism the physics are amazing and lifelike. You can really feel the damage and the strain that your aircraft goes through when it is struck by a AAA. The aircraft can be completely destroyed, if it's just damaged parts of the aircraft could be missing and the aircraft won't be able to fly properly. There are wide range of aircraft, from experimental planes to bombers and fighters. Each having their own engine sound and customisable loadouts. There are preset missions in the game or you can create your own missions.Appearance:This game is roughly fifteen to twenty years old, so the resolution does not fit most monitors this makes it difficult to see other aircraft and fine detail from a long distance away. The damage models are very good for their age, and the effects like an engine burning or where an aircraft has crashed are highly detailed and look aesthetically pleasing. There are player models which you can see in the cockpit and when you're bailing out.Sounds: each aircraft has typically a unique engine sound and unique gun sounds, the sounds are affected by speed of the aircraft and your distance away from another vehicle. They sound really realistic and in some cases can be very distinct to a certain aircraft.Maps:There are many maps, the maps span from the Pacific Islands all the way to moscow the maps themselves are massive and have a large attention to detail put into them. They vary from having a large amount of forest, too miles and miles of ocean, or even mountains to hills.Customisation:You have the ability to customise what loadout you have, what map you play on, what aircraft you face, and at what altitude you do so. You can edit what the pilot wears, you can even change both the skin and marking of the aircraft that you've chosen to play as.Conclusion: IL-2 is an extraordinary game. It has a high level of detail, it's realistic it provides a challenge. From being able to choose your own occupation, to having dogfights. You're even able to experiment with the aircraft. At only ten pounds, it is a killing of a bargain. This is a critically acclaimed classic, and should not be misinterpreted as anything other. Please keep in mind you will need a joystick with a power sensor in order to play this properly as intended, other than that it is by far the best game I have in my library.

Posted: June 12, 2016
												I'd been flying for the better part of an hour over endless, shimmering blue waves before they came into sight. At first I thought it might be just a trick of my brain, as I had been straining my eyes toward the horizon for a long time. But no, it's not my imagination, there are the faintest shadows against the sky in the hazy blue distance. First just a few, then more, and as I fly closer they elongate and begin to take shape. A squadron of heavy bombers, at least 20 of them by looks of it, and they are on their way to drop a hundred thousand pounds of high explosives on our airbase. Well, not if I have anything to say about it.I pull back on the stick, climbing above the scatted, puffy-white stratus clouds and putting the incoming bombers a few thousand feet further below me. I let them come sliding underneath, and then I roll left and dive. The Gs push me back into my seat and I feel the blood rush from my head but I modulate my dive to avoid losing consciousness. In what feels like a matter of a few heartbeats I drop out of the clouds behind the squadron and get the tail-most bomber in my sights. The tailgunner has seen me and he opens fire, but its too late. A short burst from my cannons sets their right engine on fire. Another burst and the wing snaps like a twig in a gale, the bomber pitches sharply up and then topples over to the left. Thus begins their death spiral down into the sea below, a trail of black smoke highlighting the bomber's final path. I see a few white parachutes open along that trail of smoke but the helpless bomber crew no longer interest me. I'm getting near enough to the next bomber that their gunners start to open up, and white phosphorous tracer rounds are streaking past my cockpit glass. Cool, calm, collected... I feel the exhilaration of the kill but I ride the adrenaline smoothly. My hand rests lightly on the stick, my feet adjust the rudder ever-so-gently, and the swaying of the plane around me is like an extension of my arms and legs. The second bomber's left engine is in my sights and I squeeze the trigger....10/10 Would stalk enemy bombers again.

												Since I'm a bit of a plane junkie, this game appealed to me greatly, so my review may be a bit biased.If you're the type who wants something similar to Ace Combat, look elsewhere. You won't be zooming about in the air doing on a dime turns in some super OP plane, just blasting people out of the sky left and right. This game requires a great deal of patience and skill to really play well, especially online against other people. The modeling of planes and all their related systems is really good, as it should be for a WW2 flight simulator. You can fly most major aircraft from all major sides in the war, ranging from the eponymous IL-2 ground attack plane, to a Japanese Zero or a P-51. That all being said, a joystick (preferrably HOTAS) is damn near a requirement to get the most out of this game. Without it you'll be stretching your fingers and your brain to remember all the controls on a keyboard. You can set the realism to lower levels so you won't have to worry about having to open radiator cowls, ammo counts, fuel status and the like, but IMO that takes away from the fun of the game.If you're a flight simulator junkie like me, and am willing to drop a few bucks on a good joystick setup, this game is definitely worth the price.

Posted: July 28, 2016
												Recommendation with a big asterisk.Il-2 isn't for everyone. It's not really a game but rather a WWII combat flight simulator with incredible depth and a large selection of available planes that come with great mechanical detail. Before you purchase or play this game you need to be prepared for that. Furthermore you have to prepared for the fact that there is no easy way in. You will need to spend several hours before you can even hit an enemy once. If you don't have a big interest in WWII warbirds from both sides there's nothing to keep you intrigued other than the gameplay which is incredibly customizable and deep though.Enter the big asterisk. Everything you get from the game is what you bring into it. There's no storyline, no interesting campaign, just no character to any of it, nothing to welcome you into the world of historical air combat. The "training" is laughable and the included missions are plain boring and uninspired. Unless you want to delve deep into the mission editor you're lost, the quick mission builder is less than stellar. The community is not very helpful either when it comes to modding the 15 year old engine so with every aspect of Il-2 you're basically left to your own devices. With a little effort from the developers this could have been a wonderful experience for a wider audience. Much older games like the Red Baron series have shown what an immersive campaign mode can add to a simulator. I can still recommend Il-2 though based on its mechanical strength and commendable wealth of content. Ever since my earliest childhood I've been a hardcore airplane nerd and just being able to fly my fantasy league of planes into combat with my entire keyboard scattered with shortcuts is enough to recommend this simulator to like-minded inviduals with too much time on their hands. Everyone else will be left standing in the rain. You will need patience, dedication and a good joystick and even then it's no guarantee you will like it. I can't blame anyone who never got into Il-2, personally I fell asleep playing similarly deep and realistic games like the Arma series.For those who are complaining this game is unplayable without a joystick: no sh*t, this is not war thunder.

												If you are into simulators, especially WWII flight simulators, this is a game for you. Ideally, you'd also want to use a joystick, as the control scheme is much more fluid and easy to use with a stick compared to the keyboard.Once you start the game you can choose between doing the story missions or trying out pilot school, which is intended to prepare you for the more intense story missions. There are also video tutorials available to watch, which are extremely useful and strongly recommended. The videos will teach you everything from taking off, to landing, to dropping bombs on your enemies and dogfighting.At the start, I had A LOT of trouble getting my plan to even successfully lift off the ground. Be patient, as you will probably see many "engine inoperable" notifications (if you haven't already blown up or overheated your engine by this point). The control scheme is a little spread out, but it shouldn't be too difficult to familiarize yourself with the layout. The learning curve for the game is not too steep, but it can be difficult in the beginning. Give yourself plenty of time to get used to taking off, and everything else will be easy to pick up after that.The graphics are a little dated, but when you get into a skirmish or large-scale battle, you will love the intensity of the fighting. Definitely recommend for the (war) flight simulator junkies.

												The best $10 you can possibly spend on Steam. This game is incredible. You won't find many other games that can match the challenge that IL-2 presents. The tactical depth is infinite and the difficulty is high but the satisfaction of improving your skills is immense. This is a hardcore flight simulator, so don't expect a shallow learning curve. Speed, accuracy and finesse with the controls are a must. Situational awareness is equally critical, as are reflexes, decisionmaking and tactical analysis, teamwork and communication, etc. The demands are high, but the reward is great. Of course you also have to fly your plane; proper engine management is very important, as is a basic understanding of aerodynamics and flight physics.. However, while the game DOES expect alot from you, it does also strike a near-perfect balance by introducing the challenge of a flight simulator while avoiding overly-complicated modern avionics and difficult-to-learn computer systems. cont'd..

												This is the worst stealth game I have ever played.Upon starting up the game, you are told that your name is "John 'mad' Doe." You are a freelance stealth operative who works around for the different countries during WW2.  It is then up to you to choose a country to work for and do what you do best, that is sabatoge of enemy bases. After choosing your country, you will be brought to a menu where you are given a briefing on your mission.  Here, you can customize John's loadout, equipment and even choose apropriate camoflauge for the mission.  You are then thrown into a giant open world map, with multiple routes to complete your objective. you are also sometimes given a set of more than capable AI teamates.  This is all very nice and well implemented, it's just to bad that they didn't focus more on the "game" part of this "game"The amount of controls for this game are absolutely ludicrous.  You will probably end up having to rebind and memorize over 100 different keystrokes just to make the game playable.  After that, you will of course try and move to your objective. However, the developers of this game didn't understand the concept of a "stealth" game.  Any time you try and move john around, you might as well be playing the sound of a b-52 bomber over a boombox at full volume.  It is not remotely possible to sneak around in this game.  On top of this, if you try to turn John around to fast or make to sudden a move, he will fall over to the ground faster than a boombox playing the sounds of a b-52 at full volume being hurled out the back of a b-52.You might be thinking now "Well if I can't get close to the enemy, I'll just take them out from far away."  That's just the problem.  Every weapon in the game has no silencer. You might as well be firing rockets, dropping bombs or shooting a .50 cal machine gun at them.  Finally, there is also no way to see how visible you are to enemies.  Since the maps or so open, you can literally be seen by an enemy miles away.Overall this is a poor excuse for a stealth game.  Stay away from it, and instead look at better stealth games like the original thief.

												What did we get here from the old box of games? IL-2 Sturmovik: 1946 it is!IL-2 Sturmovik: 1946 is a classic WWII plane simulator with many planes to fly. If you'd ever like a classic dogfight with a friend, this game is good. It is also a good game for stuff like LAN-parties as it can host servers on LAN-only.This game might be really old, but it is just an absolute gem. 												I can partially recommend this "game". It's an excellent simulator with a wide variety of aircraft and mission types, including carrier-based operations, and the price is great. It's difficult and you'll need to put in quite a few hours of practice before you can make successful bombing runs and shoot down other fighters, but it's fair.However, there's really not much of a game here, there's essentially no story, and there's a lot of time spent doing rather tedious things. For example, I was playing a bomber campaign and so many missions went like this: 1) take off from the carrier and get in formation (a few minutes of fun), 2) fly in a straight line for 20 minutes (boring), 3) set up a bombing run and drop bombs (2-3 minutes of great excitement), 4) spend 20 minutes flying back (boring), 5) land on the carrier (a few minutes of fun). There's time compression, but it can't be safely set very high. Sometimes the mission generator mixes it up, but the vast majority of my time was spent uneventfully flying to and from the mission areas. I'm sure it's realistic, but it's not exciting or fun.In summary, it's a great simulator that lets you do all kinds of military flying and the huge number of (mostly randomized) campaigns gives tremendous replay value, but after you get the hang of it most of your time will be spent feeling bored unless you actually enjoy flying in a straight line in formation for 30-60 minutes per mission.I've heard that the multiplayer is decent but I don't believe there's any matchmaking so you'll have to find a community if you want to try it.

												Hellooo. I used to have IL-2 Forgotten Battles, but I decided to replace it with this. I have only played a little bit, but I think it is enough to write this review. Buying the thing was pretty simple but I had problems starting the game up. It was extremely frustrating but I submitted my problem to Steam Support, got an answer instantly,  followed the instructions that they gave me and it worked perfectly. IL-2 is of course getting old, but it has it's advantages. It plays very smoothly on my computer (A windows 7 that is kinda clogged with stuff that has built up over the years) and you get more options than newer sims. I thought this would be a good purchase instead of a newer one, since I get so many aircraft. IL-2 Sturmovik Battle of Stalingrad (recently released) is a great, high-end sim, but you can only fight with Russian and German planes and during the same time of year and the same location. This was a better option for me because I can fly what I feel like flying. Just today I reanacted Pearl Harbor, then I flew a 1944 USAAF mission over Europe. Also the game has language of course, and some noseart is a little, well, you know. But this can be fixed. You can switch off subtitles, and for languages that you can understand you can simply delete the "bad word" files. And nose art files you dont approve of can be deleted also. If my instructions arent very clear, I'm sure you can look up how to do it. Anyways, the aircraft selection is wonderful, you can fly aircraft from all the major powers, (some smaller countries too). You can fly alot of stuff from 1930s biplanes, P-51s, all the way up to late WW2 jets, including some wacky German experimental aircraft. Also, a very neat feature is that you can take a picture of your face and use it to make your own pilot! You can zoom in on your plane and it's you in the cockpit! I love it. You can create your own nose art and slogans too, along with entire paint jobs. But I dont know a whole lot about that besides adding art and text to the plane. So yeah, overall I would recommend it, it works for me. "You stay classy". *clicks tongue, puts on goggles, and flies away* Merry Christmas by the way. Hopefully you'll be getting something from steam. I'm probably going to get T-72 Balkans on Fire next.

												I can partially recommend this "game". It's an excellent simulator with a wide variety of aircraft and mission types, including carrier-based operations, and the price is great. It's difficult and you'll need to put in quite a few hours of practice before you can make successful bombing runs and shoot down other fighters, but it's fair.However, there's really not much of a game here, there's essentially no story, and there's a lot of time spent doing rather tedious things. For example, I was playing a bomber campaign and so many missions went like this: 1) take off from the carrier and get in formation (a few minutes of fun), 2) fly in a straight line for 20 minutes (boring), 3) set up a bombing run and drop bombs (2-3 minutes of great excitement), 4) spend 20 minutes flying back (boring), 5) land on the carrier (a few minutes of fun). There's time compression, but it can't be safely set very high. Sometimes the mission generator mixes it up, but the vast majority of my time was spent uneventfully flying to and from the mission areas. I'm sure it's realistic, but it's not exciting or fun.In summary, it's a great simulator that lets you do all kinds of military flying and the huge number of (mostly randomized) campaigns gives tremendous replay value, but after you get the hang of it most of your time will be spent feeling bored unless you actually enjoy flying in a straight line in formation for 30-60 minutes per mission.I've heard that the multiplayer is decent but I don't believe there's any matchmaking so you'll have to find a community if you want to try it.

												31 march 15 update: THIS GAME IS UP AND WORKING AGAIN:  With a tweak...once you've installed it, right click on the game name, scroll down to properties, then choose BETAS. Then select old_version, ignore the code box, then apply. It'll start!An oldie but a goodie!IL-2 Sturmovik has developed from an Eastern Front ww2 flght sim into an absolute monster! It's detailed, unforgiving at times, takes effort to get into, and has a steep learning curve. Despite, or because of all of that, it's an awesome game. Given it's pretty old now, most mid range systems will do well with this. The graphics were good for its time, and still hold up ok in the sky. There's a huge online community of verteran players making all sorts of custom missions and skins for this game. Skins are easy to import. These days there's plenty of action for the other fronts of WW2 as well, especially in the Pacific.Damage is well modelled, flight characteristics have been well researched, with only a few glitches, and aircraft interiors are beautifully done. Oleg , the man who started all this, was insistent that no aircraft be imported until the cockpit was fully accurate.I'd recommend this for someone who has an interest in flight from this era, and is willing to put in the hours to learn to fly adequately. I'd suggest starting not in your favorite aircraft, but something more forgiving like an IL-2 to learn to fly. Eventually you'll be able to handle other aircraft no problem. Landing is a big challenge, I've played over 2000 hours on this game back in its CD only days and I'm still  more nervous about landing than combat!There's also some "what if?" aircraft included, hence the title 1946. They're fun, and make for an interesting experience, but don't add to the realism. There's some fascinating player made 1946 missions out there well worth playing.This is not for the casual gamer. I can't stress this enough. This game demands your attention and your commitment. do so and it'll reward you. A number of real-life veterans have said this game captures the difficulty of ww2 air combat. Don't expect an easy ride.

												While certainly is showing its age, it still has its strengths; such as an impressive number of available aircraft built up over the years. Where-as most games only come with a mere handful, this sim comes with literally hundreds of WW2 aircraft – and through 3rd party modification (such as CUP[www.sas1946.com]) there is hundreds and hundreds more, not just for WW2, but for WW1 through to modern. The flight models of these aircraft are also really well done – even by today’s standards. Plus it has to be said for the vast majority of these planes there is few to no alternative simulators where you will be able to fly them all in one package without huge expense or comprising flight model accuracy - at least until the newer IL-2 games have been expanded over time.Multiplayer is tricky but certainly functional and the game runs fine for me on Windows 10, but a certainly better experience with mods installed. If you have interest in WW2 aviation, or aviation in general then for the price of £6.99 for literally hundreds and hundreds of available aircraft to fly, you should have this title in your library.
